alert.note: Alert for South Central Lowlands And Southern Rio Grande Valley; Southwest Deserts and Lowlands; Southwest Mountains (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS El Paso (Southern New Mexico and extreme Western Texas)
info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued April 27 at 1:15PM MDT until April 28 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS El Paso
info.description: ...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FRIDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING FOR THE LOWLANDS OF SOUTHWEST AND SOUTH CENTRAL NEW MEXICO, THE LOWER AND MID ELEVATIONS OF THE GILA, AND EXTREME FAR WEST TEXAS... .A passing storm system will push through southern New Mexico on Friday bringing breezy to windy conditions with persisting dry air. Temperatures will be seasonably warm. North to northwest winds will be 20-25 MPH with gusts 30-35 MPH. In addition, a cold front will push through the Sacramento mountains, and across lowlands east of the Rio Grande through the day, shifting winds to north and northeast over those areas. Minimum RH will be 7-12 percent across areas west of the advancing front. Behind the front, cooler temperatures will help to raise relative humidity above RFW criteria, but shifting winds will remain strong. Fire weather conditions will improve through the evening as winds subside and relative humidity rebounds above critical levels. ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON TO 8 PM MDT FRIDAY FOR STRONG WINDS AND DRY CONDITIONS... The National Weather Service in El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa has issued a Red Flag Warning, which is in effect from noon to 8 PM MDT Friday. * WIND...Northwest winds at 20 to 25 MPH and gusts 30 to 35 MPH. * HUMIDITY...Minimum relative humidity 7 to 15 percent. * COLD FRONT AND WIND SHIFTS...A cold front will push into the region from the South Plains. Winds will turn northerly and northeasterly through the day across the Sacramento mountains, and the lowlands east of the Rio Grande. * IMPACTS...any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended. Operational impacts due to abrupt wind shifts should be considered due to the approaching and passing cold front.
info.instruction: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of strong winds, low relative humidity, and warm temperatures can contribute to extreme fire behavior.

area.areaDesc: South Central Lowlands And Southern Rio Grande Valley; Southwest Deserts and Lowlands; Southwest Mountains
